Identification.LongTitle: Regulations Implementing the United Nations Resolutions on the Central African Republic

Provision.Text: Whereas the Security Council of the United Nations, acting under Article 41 of the Charter of the United Nations, adopted Resolution 2127 (2013) on December 5, 2013, Resolution 2134 (2014) on January 28, 2014 and Resolution 2149 (2014) on April 10, 2014;
And whereas it appears to the Governor in Council to be necessary to make regulations for enabling the measures set out in those resolutions to be effectively applied;

Therefore, His Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Minister of Foreign Affairs, pursuant to section 2 of the United Nations Acta, makes the annexed Regulations Implementing the United Nations Resolutions on the Central African Republic.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in these Regulations.

Definition.Text: armed mercenary means any person who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is specially recruited to use arms and related material in the Central African Republic or uses arms and related material in the Central African Republic;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is motivated essentially by the desire for private gain;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is not a member of the armed forces of the Central African Republic; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: is not sent to the Central African Republic by a state on official duty as a member of that state’s armed forces. (mercenaire armé)

Definition.Text: arms and related material means any type of weapon, ammunition, military equipment including military vehicles, or paramilitary equipment, and their spare parts. (armes et matériel connexe)
Canadian means a citizen within the meaning of the Citizenship Act or an entity established, incorporated or continued by or under the laws of Canada or of a province. (Canadien)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: its political subdivisions;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: its government and departments and a government or departments of its political subdivisions; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: its agencies or those of its political subdivisions. (République centrafricaine)

Definition.Text: Committee of the Security Council means the Committee of the Security Council of the United Nations established under paragraph 57 of Resolution 2127 (2013) of December 5, 2013, adopted by the Security Council. (Comité du Conseil de sécurité)

designated person means a person that is designated by the Committee of the Security Council under paragraph 32 of Resolution 2134 (2014) of January 28, 2014, adopted by the Security Council. (personne désignée)
entity includes a corporation, trust, partnership, fund, unincorporated association or organization or a foreign state. (entité)

military activities means any activities conducted by state armed forces, non-state armed forces or armed mercenaries and any activities that support the operational capabilities of an armed group. (activités militaires)
Minister means the Minister of Foreign Affairs. (ministre)
MINUSCA means the United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic. (MINUSCA)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is or was employed in the service of Her Majesty in right of Canada or of a province;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: occupies or occupied a position of responsibility in the service of Her Majesty in right of Canada or of a province; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is or was engaged by or on behalf of Her Majesty in right of Canada or of a province. (fonctionnaire)

Definition.Text: person means an individual or entity. (personne)
Security Council means the Security Council of the United Nations. (Conseil de sécurité)
technical assistance means any form of assistance, such as providing instruction, training, consulting services or technical advice or transferring know-how or technical data. (aide technique)
working day means a day that is not Saturday or a holiday. (jour ouvrable)

Subsection.Text: It is prohibited for any person in Canada or any Canadian outside Canada to knowingly

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: deal in any property in Canada that is owned, held or controlled, directly or indirectly, by a designated person or by a person acting on behalf of, or at the direction of, a designated person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: enter into or facilitate any transaction related to a dealing referred to in paragraph (a);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: provide or acquire any financial or related services in respect of a dealing referred to in paragraph (a);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: make available any property to or for the benefit of a designated person, a person acting on behalf of or at the direction of a designated person or an entity that is owned, held or controlled, directly or indirectly, by a designated person; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: provide any financial or related services to or for the benefit of any person referred to in paragraph (d) or acquire any such services from or for the benefit of any such person.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not prohibit the payment of interest or other earnings to a designated person if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the payment is the result of a dealing or transaction that occurred before the person became a designated person; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the amount paid becomes subject to subsection (1).

Section.Text: Section 2 does not prohibit the provision, processing or payment of funds, other financial assets or economic resources or the provision of goods and services that are necessary to ensure the timely delivery of humanitarian assistance or to support other activities that support basic human needs in the Central African Republic by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the United Nations, including its programs, funds and other entities and bodies, as well as its specialized agencies and related organizations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: international organizations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: humanitarian organizations that have been granted observer status by the United Nations General Assembly and members of those humanitarian organizations;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: bilaterally or multilaterally funded non-governmental organizations that are participating in any United Nations humanitarian response plan, refugee response plan or other United Nations appeals for assistance or in groups of humanitarian organizations coordinated by the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, including the employees, grantees, subsidiaries and implementing partners of those non-governmental organizations while acting in those capacities;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any other person authorized for that purpose by a United Nations committee established by the Security Council acting within its mandate.

Section.Text: It is prohibited for any person in Canada or any Canadian outside Canada to knowingly

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: export, sell, supply or transfer, directly or indirectly, arms and related material, wherever situated, to the Central African Republic or to any person in the Central African Republic; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide, directly or indirectly, technical assistance or financial assistance related to the sale, supply, transfer, manufacture, maintenance or use of arms and related material to the Central African Republic or to any person in the Central African Republic.

Section.Text: It is prohibited for any person in Canada or any Canadian outside Canada to knowingly provide, directly or indirectly, to the Central African Republic or any person in the Central African Republic

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: technical assistance or financial assistance related to military activities; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: armed mercenaries.

Section.Text: It is prohibited for the owner or master of a Canadian vessel, as defined in section 2 of the Canada Shipping Act, 2001, or any operator of an aircraft registered in Canada or any Canadian owner or master of a vessel or Canadian operator of an aircraft to knowingly carry, cause to be carried or permit to be carried, arms and related material that are destined for the Central African Republic or a person in the Central African Republic.

Subsection.Text: Sections 3 and 5 do not apply to non-lethal military equipment intended solely for humanitarian or protective use, if the Committee of the Security Council has been notified in advance of its intended use.

Sections 3 and 5 do not apply to protective clothing, including flak jackets and military helmets, that is temporarily exported to the Central African Republic by United Nations personnel, representatives of the media and humanitarian and development workers and associated personnel, solely for their personal use.

Section 3, paragraph 4(a) and section 5 do not apply to an activity that is intended solely for the support of MINUSCA, the European Union training missions deployed in the Central African Republic, French forces and the forces of other member states who provide assistance and training to the Central African Republic, if the Committee of the Security Council has been notified in advance of the activity.
If the Committee of the Security Council has been notified in advance, section 3, paragraph 4(a) and section 5 do not apply to the supply of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: small arms and other related equipment intended solely for use by international-led patrols providing security in the Sangha River Tri-national Protected Area and by armed wildlife rangers of the Chinko Project and the Bamingui-Bangoran National Park to defend against poaching, smuggling of ivory and arms and other activities contrary to the national laws of the Central African Republic or its international legal obligations; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: non-lethal military equipment and related technical assistance to the Central African Republic security forces, including state civilian law enforcement institutions, intended solely for support of or use in the Central African Republic’s Security Sector Reform, in coordination with MINUSCA.

Subsection.Text: Section 3, paragraph 4(a) and section 5 do not apply to the supply of arms and related material that are intended for Central African Republic security forces, which includes state civilian law enforcement institutions, and that are only to be used in or to support the Central African Republic’s Security Sector Reform, if the Committee of the Security Council has approved the activity in advance.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Arms calibre of 14.5 mm or less
Subsection.Text: Despite (1), with respect to arms with a calibre of 14.5 mm or less and ammunition and components specially designed for such arms, unarmed ground military vehicles and ground military vehicles mounted with weapons with a calibre of 14.5 mm or less, only advance notice to the Committee of the Security Council is required.

Section.Text: Section 3, paragraph 4(a) and section 5 do not apply to an activity that has been approved in advance by the Committee of the Security Council.

It is prohibited for any person in Canada or any Canadian outside Canada to knowingly do anything that causes, facilitates or assists in, or is intended to cause, facilitate or assist in, any activity prohibited by sections 2 to 5.
The following entities must determine on a continuing basis whether they are in possession or control of property that is owned, held or controlled by or on behalf of a designated person:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: authorized foreign banks, as defined in section 2 of the Bank Act, in respect of their business in Canada, and banks regulated by that Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: cooperative credit societies, savings and credit unions and caisses populaires regulated by a provincial Act and associations regulated by the Cooperative Credit Associations Act;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: foreign companies, as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Insurance Companies Act, in respect of their insurance business in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: companies, provincial companies and societies, as those terms are defined in subsection 2(1) of the Insurance Companies Act;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: fraternal benefit societies regulated by a provincial Act in respect of their insurance activities and insurance companies and other entities regulated by a provincial Act that are engaged in the business of insuring risks;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: companies regulated by the Trust and Loan Companies Act;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: trust companies regulated by a provincial Act;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: loan companies regulated by a provincial Act;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: entities that engage in any activity described in paragraph 5(h) of the Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act if the activity involves the opening of an account for a client; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: entities authorized under provincial legislation to engage in the business of dealing in securities or to provide portfolio management or investment counselling services.

Section.MarginalNote: Duty to disclose — RCMP or CSIS

Subsection.Text: Every person in Canada, every Canadian outside Canada and every entity set out in section 11 must disclose without delay to the Commissioner of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police or to the Director of the Canadian Security Intelligence Service

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the existence of property in their possession or control that they have reason to believe is owned, held or controlled by or on behalf of a designated person; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any information about a transaction or proposed transaction in respect of property referred to in paragraph (a).

Subsection.Text: No proceedings under the United Nations Act and no civil proceedings lie against a person for a disclosure made in good faith under subsection (1).

A person that wishes to engage in any activity that is prohibited under these Regulations must, before doing so, apply to the Minister in writing for a certificate to exempt the activity from the application of the Regulations.

The Minister must issue the certificate if the Security Council did not intend that the activity be prohibited or if the Security Council or the Committee of the Security Council has approved the activity in advance.

A person whose property is affected by the application of section 2 may apply to the Minister in writing for a certificate to exempt the property from the application of that section if the property is necessary for basic or extraordinary expenses or is subject to a lien, mortgage or security interest, to a hypothec or prior claim, to a charge or to a judicial, administrative or arbitral decision.

If it is established in accordance with Resolution 2134 (2014) of January 28, 2014, adopted by the Security Council, that the property is necessary for basic or extraordinary expenses or that it is subject to a lien, mortgage or security interest, to a hypothec or prior claim, to a charge or to a judicial, administrative or arbitral decision, the Minister must issue a certificate within the following time periods:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within 15 working days after receiving the application, in the case of property necessary for basic expenses, if the Committee of the Security Council did not oppose the application;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: within 30 working days after receiving the application, in the case of property necessary for extraordinary expenses, if the Committee of the Security Council approved the application; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: within 90 working days after receiving the application, in the case of property that is subject to a lien, mortgage or security interest, to a hypothec or prior claim, to a charge or to a judicial, administrative or arbitral decision that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: was created or issued before the person became a designated person,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is not for the benefit of a designated person, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: has been brought to the attention of the Committee of the Security Council by the Minister.

Subsection.Text: A person who is a party to a contract or a gratuitous transfer may apply to the Minister in writing for a certificate to exempt property from the application of section 2 to permit them to receive payments or a transfer from a designated person or to permit a designated person to make payments or to carry out the transfer.

The Minister must issue a certificate within 90 working days after receiving the application and at least 10 working days after advising the Committee of the Security Council of the intention to issue the certificate, if it is established that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the contract was entered into or the transfer was carried out prior to any party becoming a designated person; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the payments or transfer are not to be received, directly or indirectly, by a designated person, by a person acting on behalf of, or at the direction of, a designated person or by an entity that is owned, held or controlled, directly or indirectly, by a designated person.

Subsection.Text: A person whose name is the same as or similar to the name of a designated person and that claims not to be that designated person may apply to the Minister in writing for a certificate stating that they are not that designated person.
Within 45 working days after receiving the application, the Minister must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: issue the certificate, if it is established that the applicant is not the designated person; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide notice to the applicant of his or her determination, if it is not so established.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, for the purpose of enforcing these Regulations or fulfilling any obligation under a resolution of the Security Council with respect to the Central African Republic or to respond to a request from the Security Council or any of its subsidiary organs, disclose any personal information to an official or to the Security Council or any of its subsidiary organs.
An official may receive any personal information disclosed to them under subsection (1).

An official may, for the purpose of enforcing these Regulations or fulfilling any obligation under a resolution of the Security Council with respect to the Central African Republic or to respond to a request from the Security Council or any of its subsidiary organs, disclose any personal information to the Minister.

Reserved.Emphasis: [Former sections 15 to 17, as enacted by SOR/2014-163, were replaced. See SOR/2023-70, s. 11.]

Section.Text: No legal proceedings lie in Canada at the instance of the Government of the Central African Republic, of any person in the Central African Republic, of a designated person or of any person claiming through or acting on behalf of any such person in connection with any contract or other dealing if its performance was prevented in any way by these Regulations.
For the purpose of paragraph 11(2)(a) of the Statutory Instruments Act, these Regulations apply before they are published in the Canada Gazette.
For the purpose of paragraph 11(2)(a) of the Statutory Instruments Act, these Regulations apply before they are published in the Canada Gazette.
